December 21, 1955
Mr. Earl Wynn
Communications Center
The University of North Carolina
Chapel Hill, North Carolina
Dear Earl:
Harry Skornia and my planning sub-committee met in Chicago on December 3,
just a day or so after I received a copy of your letter to Harry about the
’’American Accents” show. I presented the idea to them, of course, and the
response was generally favorable.
We are not recommending as a committee that the program be one of the
first three selected for consideration as a prestige series; we really have
too little information for that. But the group certainly thought that the
idea was worth a grant if it could be worked out. There was some concern
over two things; what seemed to us from your necessarily sketchy outline a
lack of unity and central purpose for the entire series, and some doubt
about the mechanical problems involved in long distance pick-ups. I’m sure
you oan answer these objections without any trouble. Otherwise, the idea
seemed an exciting one to Skornia, Eitzen, Vogl, and me.
You’ll be interested in knowing that the three areas which we are re¬
commending for a prestige treatment are (1) "What Industrialization Means
to America”, (2) some aspect of mental health, and (3) Geriatrics. We
feel that all three are related to the general confusion of our time and
our adding machine society, and therefore each series is somewhat connected
with the other two.
1 hope that you can work out detailed plans of the ’’Accents” idea, and
submit them for a grant to the Center, You can do this through me, if you
like, or through NAEB headquarters.
Sincerely,
Kenneth D. Wright
Director of Broadcasting
